Hi Anmol,
 
> http://dblab.ssu.ac.kr/publication/LeKi05a.pdf
>
> They seem to have done fair bit of experiments with this issue. Do you 
> think its a good idea to add a Canonicalization Rule for the same.
>

Thanks for the paper. I just briefly scanned the section on trailing 
slash normalization and the results of 50% duplication are expected 
without any normalization.
As I said, most of URLs without trailing slashes are redirects. These 
redirects also have tendency to be same documents. Often empty documents 
with same footprint, so I am not surprise that half of the requests are 
the same.
Now, I was surprise that the lost was not larger when removing the 
trailing slash. However, that depends of the order of the harvest. If 
you first crawl pages with trailing slashes and then ignore ones without 
there is likely to be no lost. Anyhow, I will have to read the paper 
more carefully; sometime normalization and canonicalization can have 
different meanings and it possible that I misunderstood the figures.

Take care,
i.




> Anmol
>
> On 12/8/06, *Igor Ranitovic* <igor@... 
> <mailto:igor@...>> wrote:
>
>     Hi Anmol,
>
>     In my experience, these two URLs are usually distinct documents where
>     the first one is redirect to the second one. So, in most cases you
>     want
>     to get them both. However, if you are not interested in replaying
>     harvested documents you can choose not save redirects by using
>     filters
>     on ARCWriter (or some other writer). Or you can easily add a new
>     regular
>     expression cannon rule to avoid getting both. In this case be sure
>     that
>     URLs that you shown below are really duplicates.
>
>     I hope this helps.
>     i.
>
>
>
>     > I am pretty certain there is something I am not doing right, just
>     that I
>     > am trying to pin point the issue.
>     >
>     > I am seeing pages
>     > http://xyz.com/target
>     > and
>     > http://xyz.com/target/
>     >
>     > both fetched separately. Any Pointers are greatly appreciated.
>     >
>     > Anmol
>     >
>
>
>
>
> -- 
> Its fun being a realist....
>
